spanishExample: ¿Adónde dices que fue el tipo?
englishTranslation: Where do you say the dude went?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dice que fue hace dos años.
englishTranslation: She says it was two years ago.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dicen que ella no es su hermana.
englishTranslation: They say she isn’t their sister.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dicen que podemos hacer lo que yo quiera.
englishTranslation: They say we can do whatever I want.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Están diciendo que él no es su hijo, es mío.
englishTranslation: They are saying that he isn’t his son, he’s mine.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: He dicho que el bebé es suyo.
englishTranslation: I’ve said that the baby(m) is hers.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Me dicen que esté ahí a las tres.
englishTranslation: They are telling me to be there at three.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Mi hermano dice que es desde *the restaurant* hasta *the plaza.*
englishTranslation: My brother says it’s from the restaurant to the plaza.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: No dices la verdad.
englishTranslation: You aren’t telling the truth.

spanishExample: No le digo la verdad.
englishTranslation: I’m not telling him the truth.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: No se lo voy a decir todo, o sea, solo las partes buenas.
englishTranslation: I’m not going to tell him it all, I mean, only the good parts.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Que yo sepa, su madre está contra eso.
englishTranslation: As far as I know, her mother is against that.
vocabIncluded: que yo sepa: "as far as I know" (idiom)

spanishExample: Sea lo que sea, se lo tiene que decir a su esposo.
englishTranslation: Whatever it is, she has to tell it to her husband.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
sea lo que sea: "whatever it is" (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Solo dices lo que tienes que decir.
englishTranslation: You just say what you have to say.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Su esposa dice que está entre esos lugares.
englishTranslation: His wife says it’s between those places.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Te decimos que no estamos en tu contra.
englishTranslation: We’re telling you that we aren’t against you.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te decimos que ya lo hemos dicho.
englishTranslation: We’re telling you that we have already said it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Te digo que vayas conmigo.
englishTranslation: I’m telling you to go with me.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te estoy diciendo que hizo eso durante *the game.*
englishTranslation: I’m telling you that he did that during the game.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te he dicho que quiero mi *sandwich* sin *veggies.*
englishTranslation: I’ve told you I want my sandwich without veggies.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Yo digo que tenemos que ir ahí, sobre todo por las casas grandes.
englishTranslation: I say that we have to go there, especially because of the big houses.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
